posts.name: Dacosta
posts.cooked:
Hi!

My team is doing the change to swerve this offseason and we are planning to use the ctre swerve program generator as a building block. Would you recommend doing that rather tan building our own? Also, for using pathplanner, would we need to change from time based to command base code?

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
My view is you should always start from someone else’s work when starting something new to you but common in the world.

Get that working (and probably keep it working in parallel for a while).

Once it initially works, decide if you want to go your own way on the motion code or just build on top of the existing.

posts.name: Rahul Yarlagadda
posts.cooked: I would recommend using the CTRE swerve generator. It does generate a whole Command-based robot project, so you will likely need to switch to Commands.

posts.name: Brad
posts.cooked:
Even without the CTRE swerve and pathplanner I recommend switching to command based.  It really helps separate your subsystem logic and keep your flow code simple.

With the CTRE Drivetrain it does generate a drive class meant for command based, but you can use the CTRE swerve control requests on time based though it would be easier with commands.

As for Pathplanner I don’t see how you could use it at all without being command based.

Again without the above I would recommend command based but with the above i not only recommend command based but strongly recommend against time based.
Do you have all CTRE Hardware for your swerve drive so you can use the CTRE Swerve Gen?

posts.name: Dacosta
posts.cooked: Thanks! That was the plan but until now we didn’t had the necessity to change to command base since we had overcome some of the challenges with timed based. But know we will invest the time in changing to command base.

posts.name: Dacosta
posts.cooked: We bought the krakens and a cannivore, now I see we are missing the pigeon right?

posts.name: 4573 Lead Mentor & Drive Coach
posts.cooked: 1 cancoder per module will also be needed

My general advice to folks is to not write swerve code. The CTRE generator is excellent and they have a version that has path planner integrated for you.

Get that up and running (which takes minutes) and focus your energy on mastering command based programming and learning pathplanner.

And great job on taking this on in June! You’ll be in great shape in 6 months.

posts.name: Otto
posts.cooked:
Honestly it might be worth just using YAGSL unless you’re certain spending the money on new ctre components makes sense within your teams budget. CTRE swerve gen is nice (gui makes setup free) but you have all summer to set up yagsl for less money.

Generally though writing custom swerve is only super useful for learning (we did it this past year and were able to pretty quickly debug all our swerve issues cause we understood most of the innards from writing a custom lib).

Also, kind of a hot take but wtv, if you’re doing well with time based rn switching to command based isn’t the best use of your time imo. On our team we’ve found that having students design/write their own paradigm rather than just using commands makes debugging and learning in general a whole lot easier. You can use path planner without refactoring your codebase (we ran state machine timed robot in 2024 and start of 25, you can pretty easily mix it in w pp with some bother). There is much less community support though and like yeah tools are geared towards commands because that’s what most people use so do whatever you think will benefit your team the most in the long run.
